110.42.text: It's often said that no word

112.48.text: rhymes with orange. Is that true?

116.14.text:
Well, rhyming can be controversial because
it often depends on pronunciation,

120.24.text:
accent and can be forced. Especially if
you use multiple

124.26.text:
words, you can force orange to rhyme with
door hinge,

128.01.text: if you want. But what we want is a perfect rhyme.

131.91.text:
A perfect rhyme is what occurs between
two words

135.43.text:
like tickle and pickle. They are perfect
rhymes because the final stressed

140.91.text:
vowel sound and all the sounds
afterwards are identical.

145.23.text:
Identical doesn't rhyme with pickle,
because even though they both

149.26.text:
end with 'ickle', identical has it stress
in the wrong place.

153.26.text:
We could rhyme them if we pronounced it
not identical

156.90.text: but instead identical. With that in mind,

160.65.text:
orange does have perfect rhymes. They
just happen to be extremely obscure,

169.25.text: Silver also has a perfect rhyme: chilver, a female lamb.

174.36.text:
Think Fact delineated even more words we
often say don't have rhymes but

178.32.text: actually do. Point is, orange does have

182.07.text: perfect rhymes, and even if it didn't, well,

185.39.text: that wouldn't make it special. Sure, monosyllabic words

189.41.text:
tend to rhyme with other words. It's believed
there are only about 100 single syllable

195.22.text: For instance, wolf, sixth, depth and filmed.

200.00.text: But considering words of all lengths,

202.34.text: it's been calculated that most English words

205.45.text: don't rhyme with anything. Don't believe me?

209.09.text:
Well, leave a comment below. The word
'comment'

212.44.text: rhymes with nothing, nor does husband, sandwich,

220.74.text: and, of course, 'nothing' rhymes with nothing.

224.23.text: Identical rhymes are even more perfect

228.03.text:
than perfect rhymes but they become so
identical at that point

232.18.text:
it's a little obvious and not really
appreciated.

235.82.text:
Identical rhymes occur when the consonant
sound before the final stressed vowel

240.00.text: between two words are also identical.

243.22.text: Sun and gun are perfect rhymes. But gun

247.18.text: and begun are identical rhymes. So are

250.58.text: offend and defend, or homonyms like

253.60.text:
son and sun. You could call the people

266.51.text:

270.24.text: though clunky, title. You can even use

273.47.text:

Letters, whose names said together some
similar to words,

322.83.text: are called Gramograms. You can't hear

325.86.text:

329.48.text:
But every letter in the alphabet is

333.51.text:
And some letters are used more
frequently than other letters

337.26.text:
in English words. Scrabble provides more
of those letters and people guess them more

341.77.text: often when playing hangman. Next time you play hangman you can take advantage of this.

346.90.text:
People will guess more letters
incorrectly if you choose a short word

350.89.text: that has few different letters. John McLuhan

hangman

357.94.text:
and he found that the most difficult word for

364.00.text:
Phantonyms aren't ghostly undead words, they're words
that appear to mean one thing but

372.04.text: Enervate sounds like it means to fill with energy but it actually means to

379.38.text: Noisome appears to mean really noisy but it actually describes something that has an

387.42.text:
In 2005, the New Oxford American Dictionary
published a new word:

394.84.text:
They said it meant the wilful avoidance of
one's official responsibilities.

399.84.text: But it didn't. They made it up

402.58.text:
as a copyright trap. If anyone copied
their dictionary

406.82.text:
the stealer wouldn't be able to explain
how esquivalience wound up in their dictionary

411.41.text: without admitting that they had copied it. Map makers often insert fake

416.07.text:

420.10.text: to trap copiers that only exist on paper,

Paper Streets & Paper Towns. The author of
The Trivia encyclopedia even placed a fake fact

429.57.text:

was certain

432.65.text:

435.82.text:
from his book. Sure enough, later the

440.84.text: as a real question. Similarly, the esquivalinece trap was used to catch

447.80.text:
But here's the thing: authorities don't
tend to respect copyright traps

454.86.text: Facts cannot be copyrighted. They belong to, and can be used by,

459.64.text: all of us. US federal courts have argued that

462.74.text:
fake facts presented as real are not
protected, because if they were,

466.86.text:
no one could share real true information
without fear

470.67.text: of sharing something protected by copyright. That said,

473.78.text:

are selected or arranged or articulated

478.86.text:
can be copyrighted. When the automobile

483.06.text:
the stylistic features of ordnance
surveys, they were forced to pay up

491.75.text:
and you cannot own a lie you made up, if
everyone believes it.

494.80.text: But you can own how you tell them.

497.88.text: Puns are great, and in 'The Pun Also Rises'

501.74.text:
John Pollock relates a fantastic story.
Puns can be traced

505.59.text:
all the way back to be epic of Gilgamesh,
where people are warned

509.59.text:
of an upcoming giant flood. They are
told that the skies will soon rain

514.37.text: kibtu and kukku. Words that mean

517.76.text:
corn and the sound corn makes when
falling on the ground.

521.08.text:
But in the story, the words are actually
puns

524.17.text: on words for misery and suffering.

528.22.text:
People who got the pun prepared and
saved their own lives,

532.60.text:
but those who failed to recognise the pun
perished in the flood,

536.94.text: which means the very oldest pun on record

540.13.text: was literally corny. Is that ironic?

545.00.text: No. Irony is one of the most

548.27.text:
debated figures of speech. The Oatmeal[.com]
famously lamented that if anyone refers

554.46.text:
ironic, the hip thing to do right now is
to call it out as being not ironic.

560.48.text:
Situational irony is what we
tend to mean when we say something is ironic.

564.89.text:
The Oatmeal defines it as "when something
happens and a reversal of expectations occurs".

570.46.text:
Dig.com's recent article on the
subject uses an even stricter definition,

574.85.text:
saying "situational irony is a direct
result of an

578.15.text: action intended to produce the opposite effect".

581.65.text: Their example is really good. If the elevators

584.98.text: at in elevator repair school are out of order,

588.47.text:
that's not really situational irony.
Instead,

591.88.text:
what would be really ironic is that if the
elevators were out of order because the

594.99.text: experts at the school had done something to them

597.62.text:
they believed would make them run forever
and never be

601.42.text:
out of order. Alanis Morissette wrote a
song called

613.63.text:
"A traffic jam when you're already late."
Not situational irony,

618.77.text:
that's just a bummer or a sad
coincidence. Patrick Cassels cleverly

623.35.text:
rewrote the song's lyrics to contain
situations that are actually

626.91.text: situationally ironic. For example, a traffic jam

630.68.text:
when you're already late to receive an
award from the municipal planning board

634.23.text:
for reducing the city's automobile
congestion

636.30.text:
eighty percent, or a black fly in your
chardonnay

640.14.text: poured to celebrate the successful fumigation of your recently purchased vineyard in southern France.

645.56.text: Now that's what I call situational irony.

648.05.text: But regardless of what Alanis intended,

651.73.text:
a close reading of the song's lyrics
reveals that irony

655.14.text:
is occurring, just not the situational
kind it's hip to argue about.

659.37.text: Instead, her song is all about dramatic irony.

665.68.text:
unaware of the significance of an event,
while other people are.

670.18.text:
Take a look at the lyrics for 'Ironic'.
The situations she describes are never

675.86.text:
ironic. At the most, they're simply
stories and similes and metaphors for it:

682.59.text: And, she adds later, life is also

685.50.text:
ironic. Dramatically ironic. These
things sound like cruddy scenarios, but they

691.22.text: actually figure, they actually make sense.

694.65.text:
Ironic is not a list of examples of
situational irony.

698.64.text: Instead, it's a treatise on dramatic irony,

702.08.text: the difference between what life knows we need

704.49.text: and what we think we need.

708.20.text:
What's ironic isn't 10,000 spoons when
all you need is at knife. It's the fact that,

713.27.text:
as Alanis believes, you have all of
those spoons,

716.47.text: because unbeknownst to you, but known by life, what you really need right now

720.38.text:
is only spoons. Or, the last thing you
need right now is a knife.

analysis of dog mitochondrial DNA
has revealed that

732.69.text: all dogs may be traceable to a localised event.

from the domestication of
